overview.description: Information for Fire, EMS, and Law Enforcement responding to suspected drug overdoses or scenes with unknown substances.
overview.critical: Scene safety is paramount. Fentanyl and analogues can be absorbed through skin or inhaled. ALWAYS use appropriate PPE before approaching.

scene_safety.name: Scene Safety & Assessment

primary_hazards.danger: Extremely potent synthetic opioids. Skin absorption and inhalation possible. Microgram quantities can be lethal.
primary_hazards.signs: White/off-white powder, pressed pills, sometimes mixed with other substances
primary_hazards.ppe: Double nitrile gloves, N95/P100 respirator, eye protection, disposable gown

primary_hazards.danger: 100x more potent than fentanyl. Used as elephant tranquilizer. Even smaller amounts deadly.
Veterinary sedative. Causes severe wounds. Does NOT respond to naloxone.
primary_hazards.signs: Mixed with fentanyl in powders and pressed pills

primary_hazards.danger: GHB, solvents, chemical precursors may be present at labs/stash houses
primary_hazards.ppe: Respirator, chemical-resistant gloves, consider HAZMAT team

scene_assessment_steps: 1. Approach cautiously - look for visible powders, pills, paraphernalia
2. Don PPE BEFORE entering scene if drugs suspected
3. Ventilate area if safe to do so (open windows/doors)
4. Identify patient(s) and assess medical needs
5. Identify visible substances - DO NOT TOUCH without PPE
6. Look for drug paraphernalia (needles, pipes, pill bottles, baggies)
7. Request law enforcement if not already on scene
8. Document scene with photos if protocol allows
if_exposed: Remove contaminated clothing carefully (avoid shaking - can aerosolize powder)
Flush exposed skin with copious water for 15+ minutes
Monitor for signs of opioid toxicity (respiratory depression, altered mental status)
Have naloxone available for responder exposure

patient_assessment.name: Patient Assessment & Treatment
vital_signs_focus: Respiratory rate (MOST CRITICAL for opioid OD)

opioid_overdose: 1. Airway management - position, suction if needed
2. Ventilatory support - BVM if inadequate breathing
stimulant_toxicity: 1. Scene safety - patient may be combative
unknown_substance: 3. Bring substance/container to hospital if safe

naloxone_protocol.indication: Suspected opioid overdose with respiratory depression
dosing: Intranasal: 4mg (one spray per nostril) - preferred for safety
IM: 0.4-2mg, repeat every 2-3 minutes as needed
IV: 0.4mg, repeat every 2-3 minutes (faster onset but requires IV access)
special_considerations: Fentanyl may require MULTIPLE doses (4-10mg total not uncommon)
Duration of action: 30-90 minutes (shorter than most opioids)
Patient may become combative when awakened (withdrawal)
Re-sedation common - transport and monitor even if patient refuses
Xylazine will NOT respond to naloxone - supportive care only
naloxone_protocol.public_access: Naloxone available over-counter in most states. Firefighters/EMS should carry nasal spray in all response vehicles.

field_test_kits.name: Field Test Kits for First Responders
field_test_kits.overview: Presumptive tests provide probable identification but are NOT definitive. Used for scene safety assessment and probable cause determination. Lab confirmation required for prosecution.

kits.name: Sirchie NARK II
kits.how_it_works: Sealed ampoules with reagent. Break ampoule, observe color change.
limitations: Fentanyl test less reliable than strips
kits.public_availability: Restricted to law enforcement in most areas

kits.name: TruNarc Handheld Analyzer
kits.how_it_works: Laser-based spectroscopy identifies molecular structure without opening container.

kits.name: DetectaChem MobileDetect
kits.how_it_works: Dry reagent pouches. Add sample, shake, photograph color with app for analysis.

kits.name: Fentanyl Test Strips (Law Enforcement Grade)
substances_detected: Fentanyl and many analogues (carfentanil, acetyl fentanyl, etc.)
kits.how_it_works: Dissolve sample in water, dip strip, read in 5 minutes. 1 line = positive, 2 lines = negative.
kits.public_availability: YES - Same strips available over-counter and through harm reduction orgs
kits.public_note: Public can obtain identical strips - see harm reduction resources

kits.name: Xylazine Test Strips
kits.how_it_works: Same as fentanyl strips - dissolve sample, dip, read.
advantages: Important for treatment decisions (won't respond to naloxone)
kits.public_availability: YES - Available through harm reduction organizations
kits.public_note: Free distribution through NEXT Distro and other harm reduction orgs

kits.name: Dräger DrugTest 5000
kits.how_it_works: Oral swab collects saliva, results in 5-10 minutes.

public_available_summary: Fentanyl Test Strips - Identical to first responder use - pharmacies and harm reduction orgs
Xylazine Test Strips - Free from NEXT Distro and harm reduction organizations
DetectaChem consumer products - Some dry reagent pouches available
Traditional reagent test kits (Marquis, Mecke, etc.) - DanceSafe, Bunk Police, etc.

documentation_and_reporting.name: Documentation Requirements
scene_documentation: Document location and condition of patient
Note position and condition of pill bottles, syringes, etc.
Witnesses present and statements if obtained
patient_care_documentation: Transport destination and condition on arrival
substance_handling: ONLY law enforcement should collect and secure evidence
Fire/EMS: Note substance location, do not collect
If substance brought to hospital with patient, document and hand off to law enforcement
Maintain chain of custody if required by protocol
Photograph any prescription bottles with patient

post_exposure_protocol.name: First Responder Exposure to Fentanyl
if_responder_exposed: Flush skin with water for 15 minutes minimum
Monitor for symptoms: dizziness, respiratory depression, altered mental status, pinpoint pupils
Do NOT use hand sanitizer (may enhance absorption)
post_exposure_protocol.panic_vs_real_exposure: Studies show most 'fentanyl exposure' calls in first responders are panic attacks, not true toxicity. True fentanyl exposure causes RESPIRATORY DEPRESSION and SEDATION, not anxiety/hyperventilation. If responder is alert and anxious, likely panic attack. Still remove from scene, provide supportive care, and monitor.
decontamination: All exposed skin should be washed
Do not contaminate vehicle - change gloves before driving
